title: 104_hr3179
content: The Act titled "Fairness to Minority Women Health Act" allows an exception to the AFDC income and resources attribution rule for certain battered aliens. The Social Security Act is amended to include provisions for battered aliens, granting exceptions for those subjected to extreme cruelty. The amended Social Security Act provides exceptions for battered aliens who are subjected to extreme cruelty, including physical injury, sexual abuse, rape, or mental abuse, perpetrated by their spouse or relative who executed the affidavit of support. The amendment made by subsection (a) regarding battered aliens will take effect 90 days after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 3 of the Food Stamp Act of 1977 is amended to protect aliens who are battered or subjected to extreme cruelty by their sponsors in the U.S. The amendment will not apply to such aliens and their children under 18 residing with them. This amendment will take effect 90 days after the enactment of the Act. Providers of Obstetrical and Gynecological Services under Medicaid must have at least one individual who can communicate in the predominant language of the area they serve. Providers of Obstetrical and Gynecological Services under Medicaid must have at least one staff member who can communicate in the predominant language of the area they serve, as determined by the Secretary based on census data. The amendments made by this subsection shall apply to services furnished on or after October 1, 1996. The Family Violence Prevention and Services Act is amended to include a new section on Domestic Violence Shelters. The provision requires shelters to have staff who can communicate in the predominant language of the area. Effective from October 1, 1996, funds will only be available to providers meeting this requirement. Additionally, a study on domestic violence and Latina women is mandated. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, in consultation with the Attorney General, will conduct a study on domestic violence cases involving Latina women. The study aims to determine the incidence of such cases and compare it with other populations, as well as analyze the causes and effects unique to these cases. A report must be submitted within 3 years of the enactment of the Act. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will submit a report to Congress detailing the findings of the study on domestic violence cases involving Latina women.
